BasicDescription.Title: Morning On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Penny Gore plays Debussy's Danse sacree, Thuille's Sextet, Berlioz's Beatrice Overture, Mondonville's Sonata, Op 3 No 3, Bruch's Romance, Op 42 and Mozart's Violin Sonata, K380.

Presented by Penny Gore

BasicDescription.Title: Composer Of The Week
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Today's look at Billy Mayerl features It must be you, Two of everything, Study 18, I breathe on windows, There's a star in the sky, Penny Whistle, Mistletoe, Four Aces Suite and Antiquary.

Billy Mayerl (1902 1959)
Mayerl In The Theatre: The 1930s.
Presented by Donald Macleod.
It must be you Two of everything Alison Taffs (mezzo soprano) Robert Petillo (tenor) Alex Hassan (piano)
Study 18 (Studies in Syncopation) Eric Parkin (piano)
I breathe on windows There's a star in the sky Alison Taffs (mezzo soprano) Robert Petillo (tenor) Alex Hassan (piano)
I breathe on windows There's a star in the sky Three Syncopated Rambles Eric Parkin (piano)
Penny Whistle Peter Jacobs (piano)
Mistletoe Eric Parkin (piano)
Four Aces SuiteR aie da Costa (piano) New Mayfair Orchestra Ray Noble
Antiquary Richard Rodney Bennett (piano)

BasicDescription.Title: CD Masters
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Rob Cowan plays Delibes' Suite (Le roi s'amuse), Handel's Sonata, Op 1 No 10, Prokofiev's Piano Sonata No 6, Handel's Jephtha, and Enescu's Violin Sonata No 3.

With Rob Cowan
Delibes: Le Roi samuse: Suite Royal Philharmonic Orchestra Sir Thomas Beecham (conductor)
Handel: Sonata in G minor, Op. 1 No. 10 Yehudi Menuhin (violin) George Malcolm (harpsichord) Ambrose Gauntlett (viola da gamba)

BasicDescription.Title: Morning Performance
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Bath Mozartfest 2002: The third of five programmes from the annual celebration of Mozart's music in Bath.

Bath Mozartfest 2002:
Stephanie Hughes with the third programme from this year's Mozart celebration including Haydn's Quartet in C, Op. 54 No.2 played by the Mosaiques Quartet and Beethoven's Variations on Bei M�nnern, welche Liebe fuhlen from Mozart's Die Zauberfl�

BasicDescription.Title: Lunchtime Concert
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Robert Plane on clarinet and Sophia Rahman on piano play Mathias' Sonatina, Bliss' Pastoral, Howells' Sonata and Finzi's Five Bagatelles, Op 23.

Chris de Souza introduces the fourth of five BBC concerts recorded in the idyllic setting of All Saints' Church, Gresford, including a tribute to Welsh composer William Mathias who died ten years ago.
Robert Plane (clarinet) Sophia Rahman (piano)
Mathias: Sonatina (Op.3) Bliss: Pastoral Howells: Sonata Finzi: Five Bagatelles (Op.23)

BasicDescription.Title: BBC Orchestras
BasicDescription.Synopsis: The BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra play Strauss' Macbeth, Saint-Saens' Piano Concerto No 2 and Rimsky-Korasakov' Scheherazade.

BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra: Great Orchestrators
Both Richard Strauss and Rimsky-Korsakov used their mastery of orchestral colour to tell stories in music. Today, we hear Strauss' thrilling account of the tragedy of Macbeth. And leader of the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra, Elizabeth Layton, takes on the role of that legendary story-teller, Sheherazade. Presented by Sandy Burnett.
Strauss: Macbeth Martyn Brabbins (conductor)
Saint Saens: Piano Concerto No. 2 Noriko Ogawa (piano)
Rimsky Korsakov: Sheherazade Alexander Titov (conductor) Elizabeth Layton (violin)

BasicDescription.Title: Making Tracks
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Music for younger listeners presented by CBBC's Angellica Bell and Adrian Dickson.

BasicDescription.Title: In Tune
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Sean Rafferty presents a selection of music, plus news from the arts world. Email: in.tune@bbc.co.uk

BasicDescription.Title: lebrecht.live
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Norman Lebrecht chairs a live debate on the topic Is Classical Music Good for You? Is the evidence credible that classical music, rather than rock or rap, enhances our abilities?

Is Classical Music Good for You?
Popular wisdom has it that Mozart turns dull kids into maths wizards, and Chopin rehabilitates hardened criminals. More sonatas and symphonies round the clock are all we need to make the world a better place. Rock and rap, on the other hand, deprave and deprive.
But is the evidence credible? Many musicians who cross categories argue that there is no moral merit in classical music, while rock can be life-enhancing.
lebrecht.live thrashes out the issue, without fear or favour.
If you have any views on this topic, email us on lebrecht.live@bbc.co.uk or phone in on 08700 100444. Lines open from 6pm.

BasicDescription.Title: Performance On 3
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Violinist Leonidas Kavakos and the London Philharmonic led by Kurt Masur play Weber's Overture (Oberon), Mendelssohn's Violin Concerto in E minor and Mahler's Symphony No 1 in D.

Kurt Masur At 75
From the Royal Festival Hall in London, Sandy Burnett introduces the third of this week's concerts by the London Philharmonic, celebrating the 75th birthday of their Principal Conductor. Tonight they perform the delightful overture to Weber's last opera Oberon, Mendelssohn's sublime, ever-popular Violin Concerto (with highly acclaimed Greek violinist Leonidas Kavakos), and Mahler's burstingly youthful First Symphony.
Weber: Overture Oberon
Mendelssohn: Violin Concerto in E minor
Mahler: Symphony No 1 in D
Leonidas Kavakos (violin) London Philharmonic Orchestra Kurt Masur (conductor)

BasicDescription.Title: Night Waves
BasicDescription.Synopsis: In an extended interview, Richard Coles talks to the critic and academic Edward Said, one of the most visible and articulate champions of the Palestinian cause.

BasicDescription.Title: Late Junction
BasicDescription.Synopsis: Verity Sharp's listening mix features electronica, jazz, world and early music and includes an ancient love song by Francis Grier.
